citations.narrative:
- The licensee was keeping track of all animal and bird births and hatchlings at the facility on a calendar. The licensee did
not record how many offspring were born/hatched and if any of the offspring were stillborn or died within a few days.
- The facility has domestic dogs and cats used for breeding comingled with the regulated species. There is no record of
animals on hand for these domestic dogs and cats.
The absence of acquisition and disposition records prevents the ability to trace and track animals in the event of animal
disease outbreak, and to ensure all parties that require a USDA, APHIS, AC license hold a current and valid license.
Every dealer other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and exhibitor shall make,
keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information concerning dogs and cats,
and animals other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her
possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer
or exhibitor. The records shall include any offspring born or hatched of any animal while in his or her possession or under
his or her control, to the extent that any identification or counting of offspring can be carried out without unduly disturbing
nesting or rearing activities.
To be corrected from this day forward, January 31, 2025

There was a Eurasian Eagle Owl housed next to three domestic dogs with no screen between the two primary
enclosures. The owl was noticed hissing at the dogs when they approached the adjacent sides of the enclosures and
barking.
Birds must be housed in a manner that does not cause trauma or stress from being housed next to natural predator
animals.
Primary enclosures that are adjacent to one another or that share a common side with another enclosure must be suitably
screened from each other or kept at a sufficient distance apart in order to prevent injury of the occupants due to predation,
territorial disputes, or aggression.
Corrected at time of inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Kristin Ray, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.75 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
- The licensee was keeping track of all animal and bird births and hatchlings at the facility on a calendar. The licensee did 
not record how many offspring were born/hatched and if any of the offspring were stillborn or died within a few days. 
- The facility has domestic dogs and cats used for breeding comingled with the regulated species. There is no record of 
animals on hand for these domestic dogs and cats. 
The absence of acquisition and disposition records prevents the ability to trace and track animals in the event of animal 
disease outbreak, and to ensure all parties that require a USDA, APHIS, AC license hold a current and valid license. 
Every dealer other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and exhibitor shall make, 
keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information concerning dogs and cats, 
and animals other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her 
possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer 
or exhibitor. The records shall include any offspring born or hatched of any animal while in his or her possession or under 
his or her control, to the extent that any identification or counting of offspring can be carried out without unduly disturbing 
nesting or rearing activities. 
To be corrected from this day forward, January 31, 2025 
3.153(a)(3) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
There was a Eurasian Eagle Owl housed next to three domestic dogs with no screen between the two primary 
enclosures. The owl was noticed hissing at the dogs when they approached the adjacent sides of the enclosures and 
barking. 
Birds must be housed in a manner that does not cause trauma or stress from being housed next to natural predator 
animals. 
Primary enclosures that are adjacent to one another or that share a common side with another enclosure must be suitably 
screened from each other or kept at a sufficient distance apart in order to prevent injury of the occupants due to predation, 
territorial disputes, or aggression. 
 
Corrected at time of inspection.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Kristin Ray, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.scientific: Ara, Anodorhynchus, Primolius, Diopsittaca spp hybrid
